speaker: NA

text_clean_combined: Good morning, Ms. Lich. My name is Paul Champ; I’m lawyer for the Ottawa Coalition of Residents and Businesses, and I have some questions for you concerning your testimony yesterday. Now, I want to start with something, Ms. Lich, that I think we both agree on; you’re not a national security threat in any way?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I don’t believe I am, no.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And I also want to make sure that we’re clear on the record; as you know, I’ve able to see a lot of financial information and so forth in other proceedings and so forth, and you did everything you could to keep track of that money and deal with it responsibly, the money that was going to your account?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Absolutely, yes, sir.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And in no way did you ever divert any of that money towards yourself improperly? And I’m saying that, that’s what I’ve seen; you dealt very responsibly in every way you could with the money?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, sir.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And you also testified yesterday you wanted to come to Ottawa for the right reasons. And by that I mean you wanted to organize with other people, bring people together over that issue, that was important to you, and send a message to the government and to your fellow Canadians; that’s what you wanted to do in coming to Ottawa?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, sir.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And you testified yesterday that you originally thought you just wanted to drive across Canada, stand in front of Parliament with some signs, and you thought that’s what the protest would be, is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I -- yes, essentially. I had no idea that it was going to become what it evolved into, yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: For sure. But then once the enormous amounts of money started flowing in through GoFundMe and, you know, people were energized around that, it opened up other options of what this protest could look like; is that fair?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I believe that everyone that was involved and that joined was in it to be listened to, to have their voices heard, as far as the mandates and the restrictions and the lockdowns went.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: But it made other things possible; like, you were able to get the stages and the sound system, and the resources to cover fuel and so forth for a much longer period than you had originally anticipated; correct?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: The donations that came into GoFundMe, as we specified in the description, was for fuel to get them to Ottawa and home.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: So...
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yeah. So -- but once you had a lot more, that opened up options that you could keep getting fuel to the trucks for a while, while they were here; that is part of the idea?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I guess that’s fair.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And we saw some -- or I read a news story about some texts that you had with Mr. Barber.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: I presume you’re aware of the news story and those texts?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, I am.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And in those texts, it’s my understanding that you had some exchanges with Mr. Barber on or about January 30th about a strategy meeting at the Command Centre about gridlocking Ottawa. Can you tell us about that?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, I can tell you what I remember, which obviously isn’t much. Gridlock is not a term that I would normally use, so -- and as the text message clearly states, that was not up to me, that was not -- never something that we advocated for.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Right.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: So -- and you have to understand that there was lots of times where we would have meetings, but we’d go in there and have a meeting about something totally different.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Right. But there was a talk about that, is that this should be the strategy going forward is keeping trucks in the streets, gridlocking downtown; that was part of the strategy at that point.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: No. No, we never wanted to gridlock the city. It was always, as I said -- especially as we saw the momentum growing and the support that we were getting, safety became my number one priority. And as you heard Mr. Marazzo testify, that was especially important to him, having a son that made frequent ambulance trips to the hospital.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Right. Unfortunately we heard that he didn't necessarily know about all the streets. He didn't know about Kent Street, for example, which even Mr. Barber acknowledged was shut down the whole time. So -- but you didn't have any visibility into that. That wasn't part of your responsibility I gather.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: No.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Now, I want to ask you some questions about the horns. You testified yesterday that at some point, even for you, the horns became a bit too much; you couldn't even carry on a conversation on the sidewalk when all those trucks were blaring?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: At times, yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And the -- I think I had seen video once when you were talking when all the semi-trucks when they blow their horns it's just crazy.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: M'hm.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: That was the experience, was it not?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, I think that's taken out of context. Are you referring to the video that I made?
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And I believe I said it was music to my ears. That was within a couple of days of getting there, and there was a lot of excitement and it was a very jovial atmosphere.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: But Ms. Lich, I know you strike me as a very reasonable person. You would agree with me that, you know, having a big rig, a semi-truck idling right in front of your house 24 hours a day, emitting diesel fumes, honking horns prolonged periods during all day, sometimes at night, that's not reasonable to a person that lives there. Would you agree?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: As I said yesterday, when I was in my hotel room I didn't really notice it, the horns honking, and I was right downtown.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: But you wouldn't want a big rig to pull up, for example, in front of your parents' home and park and idle for 24 hours a day for several weeks honking their horn. You wouldn't want that, would you Ms. Lich?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, Mr. Champ, my ex-husband was a tool push on a drilling rig, and I have spent many days on the site of a drilling rig, and there is a lot of diesel fumes and there is a lot of noise.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yeah, it's not pleasant is it?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: It is what it is.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yeah, but then you get to home. You get to get away from that noise and those diesel fumes; right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Not when you're living onsite, no.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Now, I want to ask you some questions about the injunction. We -- on February 4th to the 5th, you heard about that there was a motion from the residents of Ottawa to get an injunction to stop the horn honking; correct?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And we heard from Mr. Wilson a bit about that, that there was a meeting of the board or the leadership group about what to do, and there was a decision to oppose the injunction; correct?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I had never opposed the injunction.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Well, you swore an affidavit to impose the injunction, Ms. Lich, let's be clear on that; right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, once it was imposed, of course we weren't going to go against the injunction.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Well, no, there was a court hearing on Monday, February the 7th, where Mr. Wilson represented you, and Mr. Barber, and Mr. Dichter, who were named individuals on it, to oppose the injunction. You were -- you weren't aware that that's what the position you were taking?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I don't recall that, but if you say so, then...
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And you swore an affidavit in support of that position, which I should say swore an affidavit that the injunction should not be granted?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: If you say so. I have sworn a lot of affidavits, so if you say so.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Is it fair to say there was a lot going on?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: There was a lot going on.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: It was hard to follow all the different things that were happening?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And you may not have known exactly what the team was doing on some of those issues?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I guess that's fair to say.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Okay. Now, Mr. Wilson told us yesterday that on the board there were some who -- there was a bit of a division on the board. Some felt that, "yeah, the horns are a bit too much, and you know, maybe we shouldn't oppose this injunction", and some were like, "no, we should oppose it." Do you recall that meeting?

text_clean_combined: I was probably there, but as I said, I was in and out of a lot of meetings ---
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Right.

text_clean_combined: --- so I don't recall that specifically.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Okay. And you testified yesterday that once the injunction was issued you worked very hard or worked really hard to see that it was adhered to. Do you recall your testimony on that?

text_clean_combined: Yeah, the truck captains did for sure, yes.

text_clean_combined: Right. But you, yourself, you didn't do anything directly to ensure that the Order was adhered to, did you?

text_clean_combined: I don't believe I did, no.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: No. You didn't post any videos or make any statements on your social media account attempting to discourage the truckers from blowing their horns?

text_clean_combined: But you didn't put up anything on it before it was deleted?

text_clean_combined: No, I did not, no.

text_clean_combined: And you also, you never posted a copy of the court's injunction Order or the terms of it in any way on any of your social media; correct?

text_clean_combined: I don't believe so, no.

text_clean_combined: And were you aware that that was a term of the court Order that you were supposed to do that?

text_clean_combined: I don't believe so.

text_clean_combined: So Mr. Wilson may not have communicated that to you?

text_clean_combined: He may have. Again, it was very chaotic times.

text_clean_combined: Now, February 4th, that's Friday, that was the -- well, I'll give the day because I'm sure it was like a ---

text_clean_combined: It was a blur, yeah.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yeah. I'm sure your days were crazier than mine, but I have a bit of a sense of what you were going through. February -- Friday, February the 4th, that's the day that GoFundMe issued the statement saying they're shutting off the -- shutting down the ---

text_clean_combined: --- fundraiser and they were going to return all the money to the donors. Do you recall that day?

text_clean_combined: I do.

text_clean_combined: And when GoFundMe shut you down, you lost what was potentially access to $10 million; correct?

text_clean_combined: Correct.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And GoFundMe put out a statement that day saying, quote, "This previously peaceful demonstration has become an occupation." Do you recall that?

text_clean_combined: I do.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And by that point, you had also, I gather, had been following some of the news stories, some of the reporting talking about the negative impact that the protest was having on residents, you know, caused by the blocking of streets and the honking. Were you following that?

text_clean_combined: I didn't have a lot of time to read the news, to tell you the truth.

text_clean_combined: That was probably around that same time, yes.

text_clean_combined: So that was a bit of a rotten day, losing 10 million, being sued for 10 million?

text_clean_combined: You could say that I guess, yes.

text_clean_combined: Now, did you consider or talk about with anyone else maybe working on an exit strategy at that point?

text_clean_combined: We had been in talks about that shortly after the legal team arrived, actually.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And after that one day, when GoFundMe shuts you down, did you -- would that have been a time for you to start thinking about shutting down the protest or coming up and saying, "Hey guys, we sent our message", and going home? Was that ever part of the discussion?

text_clean_combined: Not to my knowledge. As I said yesterday, we were waiting to be acknowledged by somebody in the Federal Government who was willing to come and listen to what we had to say.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Right. But -- and -- but you told us yesterday also, another factor was that the lawyers from the Justice Centre for Constitutional Freedoms, they had showed up and they were giving you advice, they were supporting you by that point; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes. Yes, sir.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: They had been there a day or two by that time?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, sir.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And is it fair to say that without them you might have considered packing it in?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I don't know. That's really hard to say.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: So on the Friday, February the 4th, GoFundMe shuts you down, you're sued for $10 million. Then on the Sunday, February the 6th, the City of Ottawa declared a state of emergency. Do you recall that?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And then the next day, on Monday, the 7th, the court issued the horn injunction. So did you start thinking then, or was there any discussions then about maybe the protesters should start packing it in?

text_clean_combined: There might have been. I know, again to reiterate, we were very focussed on being heard and having our concerns listened to.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And then on February the 11th, Premier Ford in Ontario, they declared a state of emergency about what was happening in Ottawa. Do you recall that?

text_clean_combined: Not specifically the date, but I don't recall that happening, yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Weren't you getting the -- you testified yesterday, Ms. Lich, that while no one told you to leave, the police weren't telling you to leave, all of these things, you know, the Premier, the Mayor, the courts, GoFundMe, that wasn't a message, the City of Ottawa, residents suing, that wasn't a message that maybe it was time to leave?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, we had a message too.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yeah. And so -- and that was more important than what the people of Ottawa ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: After the stories that I heard coming across Canada that were absolutely heartbreaking after two years of lockdowns and restrictions, yeah.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Now, you reached the deal with he Mayor around Sunday, the 12th, I believe or ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: -- the 13th. No, the 13th ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: 13th, I think.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: --- or something like that, that's right. And the Freedom Convoy put out a statement about the deal. You recall that?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, I do.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And in the statement you said things like you never wanted to impact the residents of downtown Ottawa?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And you wanted to agree to the deal to relieve the pressure on the people in downtown Ottawa?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Absolutely, sir.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Right. Because there had been pressure on the people of downtown Ottawa by that point?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, as I said, we didn't want to create a big disruption to them. We wanted to be respectful to the citizens of Ottawa, for sure.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Because from January 29 until February the 13th, you recognise it wasn't very respectful to the people of downtown Ottawa?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, what I will say is that I was approached by hundreds of Ottawa citizens who had come out to support. I was approached by federal government employees who were donating items to the protesters. We had a lot of support in Ottawa from the Ottawa citizens.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Except for those that are suing you, I guess.
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I guess, yeah.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And the mayor, who was elected by the citizens of Ottawa, he apparently wasn't supportive of you staying downtown?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: He wasn't, and I give him great credit for being willing to sit and talk to us.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yeah, and let's just be clear here, Ms. Lich, no one was asking you to leave completely. It was about moving the trucks and having the trucks stop idling out in front of residences and blowing the horns all night and day. That was the big ---
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: --- message; wasn't it?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Now you testified yesterday that once the Emergencies Act was issued and it looks like there was going to be action, law enforcement moving in, you testified that you encouraged people to leave; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: That's correct.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: But you didn't do that on social media in any way; correct?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I did not.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: So it was just people who you saw face-to-face you were telling them to leave?

text_clean_combined: Yes, primarily our people from our team also.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: You didn't think maybe it would be better you had so much influence on people who were here in Ottawa protesting that you should put it out on social media, that, hey, you guys, maybe it's time for us to leave?

text_clean_combined: I -- obviously, I didn't.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Well, and obviously, another thing that you didn't, Ms. Lich, is, from my understanding of your testimony yesterday, you suspected you were about to be arrested, and you went out to the street to ask the police officers, or have someone ask the police officers if they were looking for you; right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, that's true.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And you went out with someone who could record the arrest when it occurred; right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Everybody has a cell phone these days.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: For sure. And when you were arrested, I didn't hear Commission counsel ask you this, but as you were being arrested, you were yelling, "Hold the line"; correct?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes. Well, one of the road captains that I was with said it and I repeated it back to him, yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Right. And by that statement, I take it you weren't encouraging the other protesters to leave Ottawa; were you? You were encouraging them to stay to hold the line; correct?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, you know, that's a matter of perspective. My perspective on hold the line means stay true to your values in the face of diversity.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Right. But you'd agree with me, Ms. Lich, that some people who were protesting, who were following you at that time, when they saw that message, they would have interpreted to hold the line to stay, hold the line, don't leave Ottawa. Some might have interpreted that way; would you agree?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I can't speak for what -- how - - what other people think.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: You don't think that's -- well, when you speak and you've got that kind of a platform, you recognise that people are listening to you, you have a great deal of influence on those people?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Well, again, it comes down to how you define the term, I suppose.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: So just assist me with this, Ms. Lich, I'm just -- I'm trying to reconcile you telling us that you were encouraging people to leave, but you didn't put anything out on social media, but then you were with only one or two people at the time you were arrested, someone that you -- you knew who recorded that video; don't you?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I do, yes.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yeah, you know that person personally?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: I do, yeah.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Yeah, and so they recorded it. You were aware, you saw them recording; right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Yes, I did.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: And then you yell out hold the line, because you wanted the people to stay in downtown Ottawa; is that right?
speaker: MR. PAUL CHAMP

text_clean_combined: Again, I was repeating what one of the road captains had said to me.
speaker: MS. TAMARA LICH

text_clean_combined: Sure. It's David Migicosvky, Counsel for the Ottawa Police Service. We have a very real concern with respect to the witness panel of Chris Deering and Maggie Dingman. speaker: MR. DAVID MIGICOVSKY

text_clean_combined: You mean they weren’t on the original list?
speaker: COMMISSIONER ROULEAU

text_clean_combined: Correct. It appears that both of these individuals, from their statements, are going to give evidence about the circumstances of their arrest by unknown officers. I’ve been able to determine in one case that it was not an OPS officer, one of them, but we are trying to find out information. These are arrests that took place on February 18th, after the invocation of the Emergencies Act. These individuals were not arrested pursuant to the Emergencies Act. They were arrested based on common-law powers and the Criminal Code. And my concerns really are two-fold. Firstly, the information we say is not relevant to your mandate under the Act, and the second question is one of procedural fairness. There were over 275 arrests made by the police in that period of February 18th to the 20th. None of the police witnesses were asked specifically about those arrests, no documents were requested. The last police witness who testified in this proceeding was on Wednesday, October 26th. Had those witness statements been provided prior to the completion of the police witnesses, then at the very least, we could have asked our witnesses to provide evidence with respect to the arrest plan, with respect to the circumstances of the arrest of those two individuals, and the other 275 people who were arrested. I am not faulting Commission Counsel. I understand that the statements were provided to them and they provided them to us immediately after. But it was two days after the last witness testified. Those statements were in the -- those were witnesses who are here represented by counsel, they had an obligation to produce documents. They chose, deliberately or otherwise, to not present that evidence and not allow me, then to respond to it. And it’s obvious that some of that information, they had beforehand. And in fact, to add to the procedural unfairness, last night, we received an email from counsel for the Convoy organizers attaching seven more videos that also would have existed that were not disclosed. There’s no explanation for why the Convoy organizers have not had to follow the same rules as everyone else. Those statements, even if they were relevant, and I don’t concede that they are, should have been provided prior to police witnesses testifying. It creates a serious and irreparable breach of procedural fairness to have you left with two arrests out of 275, which I am unable to provide evidence in response to, both those specific arrests, as well as the arrest plan in general. And there are, I say, two possible solutions. The first is to not allow that evidence to be heard. It’s not relevant to your mandate. And even if it was, it would be very difficult to draw any conclusion from the evidence of two individuals out of 275 arrests when you’ve heard no evidence about any of the arrests of anyone else, or the arrest plans, or any explanation of those two particular arrests. Alternatively, if you are inclined to allow that panel to testify, including adding new documents that were not on the database and were provided last night, then the OPS must, we say, as a matter of procedural fairness, be allowed the opportunity to call another witness to provide evidence about the arrest plans and the exercise of use of force options in connection with the exercise of police powers generally and specifically with respect to the scene that the officers encountered on February 18. You have not heard about what is involved when a Public Order Unit has to exercise tactical options. The Commission didn’t lead this evidence, nor did we. Similarly, we didn’t provide any documents surrounding those arrests. So while my first submission is that you should not allow this evidence, as an alternative, if you are inclined to do so, then I would ask for the opportunity to call evidence so that in fairness, the police witnesses can address what should have bene put to them by the Convoy organizers and which, for some reason, was not. text_clean_combined: I believe last we time we spoke, so when the processing line was finished, after the two hours of standing in the freezing cold, not able to sit or kneel, and denied my medication again, I was then -- I had my information taken, I was then placed in the back of a squad car. They read me what I was being charged with, which was public obstruction and mischief. So I said I understood. The police officer then -- the police officer then left the vehicle for five minutes. He came back and he said, “Well, today’s your lucky day. You’re not being charged.” I said, “That’s great.” I said, “Can I know what’s -- why that changed?” He said, “No, you don’t need to know that.” So at that time, I felt that it was my understanding that I’m free to go because I’m not being charged with anything. Then the next five, 10 minutes they put me in a paddy wagon with no direction. They didn’t say, “Go in here.” So, again, I mean, I had no choice. I go in the paddy wagon. I’m there for 25 minutes. I don’t know where I’m going, don’t know how long I’m there. Eventually, the paddy wagon does fill up over the next couple of hours. Then they drive us around for approximately half an hour to 40 minutes. It was very hard to tell because there’s no windows, of course, in the paddy wagon; you know, there’s no concept of time. They then drove us to a Public Works building that was 10.2 kilometres away from Parliament Hill. When they let us out of the paddy wagons, they gave us our possession back. They gave us no paperwork. The police officer came out and he gave us a stern warning and said, “You don’t come back to Ottawa, or you’ll be charged.” They gave us all our possessions back and -- sorry; most of us, due to the cold, our cell phones had died. No-one had any money; no-one had any masks. We couldn’t go into the building to make a phone call. So we were stranded. So we were forced to walk to a Wendy’s that was -- and I forget the approximate distance; we had to walk from that Public Works building in the snow, in the freezing cold to a Wendy’s. I had a called a friend that I had just met prior the night -- on the 17th, I met someone for five minutes and he said, “If you need anything in Ottawa...” And this is the type of people we met in Ottawa. I met him for two minutes, five minutes, and he said, “If you need anything, you call me and I’ll pick you up right away,” and whatever. And he did exactly that. I picked him up -- I called him at Wendy’s, I said, “Can you please us up? We have no money. We have no means. We don’t know where we are, we’re not from Ottawa.” It was just -- I never thought that I would get dumped out of the seat like trash by my -- by the police. It was ---

text_clean_combined: So in the initial -- I would say close to initial two weeks, I thought that Chief Sloly was pretty fair in his remarks regarding the convoy, you know, understanding his position as the Chief of Police of the City of Ottawa, but I thought that he was pretty unbiased. And I noticed at that time, that was -- that also coincided with a lot of that same rhetoric from the legacy media, and, you know, we’d already heard and seen the Prime Minister using similar language. And so I felt that that was -- that was definitely heightening the anxiety of the overall crowd, the fear that they were going to be labelled such and dealt with as such by law enforcement because they were under so much pressure from the -- from the different levels of government. And there was also -- I believe that was right around the same time that there was also -- they were being denied access to service, some of the portable toilets. So, I mean, you’re denying people their basic sanitation needs. And there was also information beginning to circulate about the involvement of CAS, or Children’s Aid Society, I believe is what that stands for. And that, to me, was -- that was a clear red flag to me that if you are deliberately trying to provoke people to take action, if you make them believe that you’re going to take their kids away, that’s going to elicit a very strong emotional response, and I believe that that was deliberately done in order to bully the Freedom Convoy protesters.
